title: Getting Started
text:
What is Holos
The Holos model estimates greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and changes in soil carbon content on Canadian farms, helping users explore ways to reduce emissions and increase soil carbon content. Users can input farm-specific data and adjust management practices such as livestock diets or farming practices. The model utilizes climate, soil, and agronomic data to calculate emissions from a variety of sources, including crops, livestock, and energy use. Documentation and FAQs are available on GitHub Learn more


What is PyHolos
PyHolos is a model that integrates the Holos greenhouse gas emissions calculation module into the LiteFarm framework, specifically focusing on nitrous oxide (𝑁2𝑂) emissions from crop residues. It enhances the original Holos model to provide more accurate calculations of 𝑁2𝑂 emissions related to crop residue management.



PyHolos Structure




Goal
Our project will work to enhance the existing emissions model, PyHolos, by incorporating plot-level interventions and increasing the dynamicity of the model parameters, with the hope of making the model more applicable to different regions. Throughout this process we aim to base our work in agroecological and agronomic principles, while also contemplating farmer accessibility and implementation. Specifically, we intend to achieve the following objectives:
Update the existing PyHolos model to increase the dynamicity of the model equations, making sure to reinforce this work with agronomic principles. The initial focus will be on expanding across Canada, then to other regions of the world.
Utilize experimental data from the UBC farm as a test bed for the PyHolos model to better inform model parameters. For instance, we hope to draw on the cause-and-effect relationships established through the numerous agricultural experiments conducted at the UBC Farm to help us identify the emission contributions generated by specific farming inputs and practices.

title: Getting Started
text:
What is Holos
The Holos model estimates greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and changes in soil carbon content on Canadian farms, helping users explore ways to reduce emissions and increase soil carbon content. Users can input farm-specific data and adjust management practices such as livestock diets or farming practices. The model utilizes climate, soil, and agronomic data to calculate emissions from a variety of sources, including crops, livestock, and energy use. Documentation and FAQs are available on GitHub Learn more


What is PyHolos
PyHolos is a model that integrates the Holos greenhouse gas emissions calculation module into the LiteFarm framework, specifically focusing on nitrous oxide (𝑁2𝑂) emissions from crop residues. It enhances the original Holos model to provide more accurate calculations of 𝑁2𝑂 emissions related to crop residue management.



PyHolos Structure




Goal
Our project will work to enhance the existing emissions model, PyHolos, by incorporating plot-level interventions and increasing the dynamicity of the model parameters, with the hope of making the model more applicable to different regions. Throughout this process we aim to base our work in agroecological and agronomic principles, while also contemplating farmer accessibility and implementation. Specifically, we intend to achieve the following objectives:
Update the existing PyHolos model to increase the dynamicity of the model equations, making sure to reinforce this work with agronomic principles. The initial focus will be on expanding across Canada, then to other regions of the world.
Utilize experimental data from the UBC farm as a test bed for the PyHolos model to better inform model parameters. For instance, we hope to draw on the cause-and-effect relationships established through the numerous agricultural experiments conducted at the UBC Farm to help us identify the emission contributions generated by specific farming inputs and practices.

title: Formula
text:
we do not consider these three variables in the Pyholos yet:

\(N_2O_{N_{SNdirect}}\),
\(N_2O_{N_{CRNmindirect}}\)
\(N_2O_{N_{ONdirect}}\)

\(N_{CropResidues}\) depend on the crop should be the same?
\(EF_{Topo}\) depends on P and PE
\(RF\_TX\) depends on soil texure

title: Formula
text:
EF (Emission Factor)

\[
EF = EF_{Base} * RF\_NS * RF\_Till *RF\_CS * RF\_AM
\]
\[
(N_2O_{N_{SNdirect}} + N_2O_{N_{CRNmindirect}} + N_2O_{N_{ONdirect}} + EF_{Topo} \times RF\_TX \times \frac{1}{0.645} \times RF\_NS \times RF\_Till \times RF\_CS \times RF\_AM \times ((AboveGround_{residue\_N} + BelowGround_{residue\_N})*area))
\]

title: Formula
text:
\(N_{CropResidues}\)

\[
N_{CropResidues} = (AboveGround_{residue\_N} + BelowGround_{residue\_N})*area
\]

Above Ground Residue Nitrogen

For Annual and Perennial Plants,
\[
AboveGround_{residue\_N} = [\href{#grain}{Grian_N} + \href{#straw}{Straw_N}]
\]
For Root Plant,
\[
AboveGround_{residue\_N} = \href{#straw}{Straw_N}
\]
For Cover and Silage Plant, \[
AboveGround_{residue\_N} = \href{#grain}{Grian_N}
\]


Below Ground Residue Nitrogen
 For annual plants:
\[
BelowGround_{{residue_N}} = [\href{#root}{Root_N} + \href{#eroot}{Exudate_N}]
\]
For perennial plants:
\[
BelowGround_{residue_N} = [\frac{S_r}{100} \times \href{#root}{Root_N}] + \href{#eroot}{Exudate_N}
\]
For root plant, \[
BelowGround_{residue_N} = \href{#grain}{Grian_N} +  \href{#eroot}{Exudate_N}
\]
For cover and silage plant,
\[
BelowGround_{residue_N} = \href{#root}{Root_N} + \href{#eroot}{Exudate_N}
\]


Nitrogen content of the root returned to the soil


\({Root}_N = \frac{C_r}{0.45} \times \frac{N_r}{1000}\)



Nitrogen content of the exudates returned to the soil


\({Exudate}_N = \frac{C_e}{0.45} \times \frac{N_e}{1000}\)


Nitrogen content of the straw returned to the soil


\({Straw_N} = \frac{C_s}{0.45} \times \frac{N_s}{1000}\)




Nitrogen content of the grain returned to the soil


\({Grain_N} = \frac{C_{p\_to\_soil}}{0.45} \times \frac{N_p}{1000}\)



Carbon input from product
\(C_{p\_to\_soil} = C_p \times \frac{S_p}{100}\)

\({Exudate}_N = \frac{C_e}{0.45} \times \frac{N_e}{1000}\)

\(C_r = C_p \times \frac{R_r}{R_p} \times \frac{S_r}{100}\)
\(C_e = C_p \times \frac{R_e}{R_p}\)

${Grain_N} = $
${Straw_N} = $

\(C_{p\_to\_soil} = C_p \times \frac{S_p}{100}\)
\(C_s = C_p \times \frac{R_s}{R_p} \times \frac{S_s}{100}\)

$C_p = [(yield + yield ) (1 - )] $

yield is defined by users
moisture content is default based on the crop type
Carbon concentration is default based on the crop type
\(S_p, N_p, N_s\)






Emission Factor
For humid environment:\(P > PE\)
\[
EF_{{CT}_{P}} = \exp^{0.00558 \times P - 7.7}
\]
\[
EF_{Topo} = EF_{{CT}_{P}}
\]
For dry environment \(PE \geq P\)
\[
EF_{{CT}_{PE}}= \exp^{0.00558 \times PE - 7.7}
\]

For non-irrigated sites:

\[
EF_{Topo} = (EF_{{CT}_{PE}} \times FR_{Topo}) + [EF_{{CT}_{P}} \times (1 - FR_{Topo})]
\]
For irrigated sites, the assumption is that the irrigation amount is equal to PE - P, thus making P = PE,
\[
EF_{Topo} = EF_{{CT}_{PE}}
\]
Variables:

\(EF_{CT}\): Ecodistrict-level emission factor (\(kg \, N_2O\text{-}N \, (kg \, N)^{-1}\))
\(P\): Annual growing season precipitation (May – October)(mm)
\(PE\): Growing season potential evapotranspiration, by ecodistrict (May – October) (mm)

\[
EF_{Base} = (EF_{Topo} \times RF\_TX) \times \frac{1}{0.645}
\]
\[
EF = EF_{Base} * RF\_NS * RF\_Till *RF\_CS * RF\_AM
\]
\[
EF = (EF_{Topo} \times RF\_TX) \times \frac{1}{0.645} * RF\_NS * RF\_Till *RF\_CS * RF\_AM
\]
\[
N_{CropResidues} = (AboveGround_{residue\_N} + BelowGround_{residue\_N})*area
\]
